Ottawa, October 17, 1932.

Dear Mr. Dill:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the painting of the interior of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that Mr. Agent Lewis is being requested to report regarding the cost and to give an estimate of the quantity of paint required. If this work is carried out, it is considered that it should be done during the coming Christmas holidays, in order that it would not interfere with the regular classroom work. If the cost is not excessive, the Department will approve of having the work done.

I am having a set of Corona Flash Cards sent to you, also some requisition forms. Twenty-four tooth brushes were sent to you on the 27th ultimo. If these were received, it is thought they should be sufficient for the number of pupils in attendance.

With best regards,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

Geo. Dill, Esq.,
Teacher, Sucker Creek Indian Day School,
Little Current, Ont.
Ottawa, October 15, 1932.

Sir:

A requisition has been received from the teacher of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School for a supply of paint sufficient to paint the interior of the school building. He states the walls are in a filthy condition and that it would be necessary to first have them washed, and that the painting could be done by the Indians. He states it would take between three and five gallons of paint for two coats.

I would request that you give this matter your consideration. If the cost of having the painting carried out would not be high, the Department would favourably consider authorizing same. You might also state, if you approve of the work being done, when you would recommend that same be performed. It is considered that it should be carried out during the coming Christmas holidays, in order that it would not interfere with the regular classroom work. If you recommend same, you should state the quantity of paint required and the approximate cost of the labour in having the painting carried out. We are informing the teacher that this matter is being referred to you. A report giving the information asked for at your early convenience is requested.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacIntosh
Acting Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning,
Ont.
From Mr. Southland:

I should have mentioned in my letter of the 12th instant that I had spoken to Mr. Lewis about this paint before I wrote to you. If you want a straight estimate on the work you will find one in the estimate submitted in connection with the proposed repairs. My thought was to employ Indian labor to lessen the cost.

Also I should suggest closing the school on Friday and having the work done over the weekend. I can reach this following Saturday to make up for this. We might as well have the benefit of the sunshine!

The toothbrushes I send ahead of me were distributed by the teacher and have been taken away. The number I asked for was needed to equip one to each child. I am anxious to have tooth-brush shall in school.

I gave Mr. Lewis a requisition for some soap etc. for the school. Be good to it!

Yours truly,

George Scott

Sir:

I have the honour to report that the teacher in Sucker Creek Indian Day School, Mr. G. Dill, has asked for the following articles to be furnished for use in the class-room.

6 bars toilet Soap
6 " laundry Soap for scrubbing
4 yards Towelling
6 drinking Cups
1 Sauce Pan and lid
1 Dishpan
6 lamp Mantles
1 gal. Gasoline
1 Axe Handle
2 Tea Towels.

He also asks for a supply of Cod Liver Oil, and that soup be supplied for the pupils to serve with their midday meal instead of cocoa which was served as a hot drink during the last winter past.

As soap, towelling, cups, mantles, gasoline and an axe handle are required at this school I would recommend the purchase, and if the Department approve of a hot drink being served to the pupils with their midday meals it will be necessary to furnish a dishpan, sauce pan and tea towels. The cost of a supply of cocoa, milk and sugar will be much less than a supply of canned soups, therefore, I would recommend that hot cocoa be served if the Department will approve of a hot drink being served in the Day Schools during the incoming winter months.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Little Current, Ont.
October 24, 1932.

To Mr. Sutherland:

You will remember that the Dept. placed an order for some seats for the Little Current School on July 12th. These were sent by an inland line and I signed the accounts in Ottawa. They were not opened until my return and I found that the following were missing.

1 # 2 Front
1 # 2 Rear

This is undoubtedly my fault—and I don't know what can be done. I am wondering if I could write to the firm. I really need the seats and they may replace them. Certainly they were not in the two cases received.

I shall be glad to know how to act in their behalf.

Yours truly,

George Hill
Ottawa, October 26, 1932.

Dear Mr. Dill:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, informing the Department that one No. 2 front and one No. 2 rear were missing from the equipment supplied by the Globe Furniture Company for the use of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School.

In this connection I have to say that I am taking this matter up with the above Company and requesting them to check up on this shipment. They are being requested, if they supplied the front and rear seats, and they were lost after arrival at Little Current, to duplicate the order and supply another No. 2 front and No. 2 rear, and to forward their account, in triplicate, to you covering the cost. You should certify this account in the usual manner and forward it to the Department for payment. It is thought the above Company, no doubt, forwarded the full number of front and rear seats, but something happened to them after their arrival at Little Current and before your return to the school. I presume you have made full enquiry.

Regarding the painting of the interior of the school, we are awaiting a reply from Mr. Agent Lewis. I am again drawing this matter to his attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

Geo. Dill, Esq.,
Teacher, Sucker Creek Indian Day School,
Little Current, Ont.
Ottawa, October 26, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, regarding the request of the teacher of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School to be supplied with materials as mentioned therein.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- 6 bars toilet soap,
- 6 lbs laundry soap,
- 4 yds towelling,
- 6 drinking cups,
- 1 saucepan and lid,
- 1 dishpan,
- 6 lamp mantles,
- 1 gal. gasoline,
- 1 axe handle.

Please obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, to which you should attach a proper voucher form, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

The Department will approve of a hot drink being served to the pupils at midday, and you may purchase the supply of cocoa and sugar required for the purpose. We understand that the Indian children can supply the milk required. Only the quantity of cocoa and sugar needed for the balance of the present school year should be supplied at the present time, and certified accounts covering the cost should be forwarded for payment. We are not prepared to supply canned soup.

I would refer you to official letter of the 15th instant regarding the painting of the interior of the school building, and would be pleased to have a reply thereto.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning,
Ont.
Ottawa, October 26, 1932.

Gentlemen:

I wish to refer you to letter dated July 12th, last, placing an order with your firm to supply a number of front and rear seats for delivery at Little Current, Ont. The Department is now informed that the cases in which these desks were packed were not opened until recently, and that it was found the following were missing:

1 No. 2 Front,
1 No. 2 Rear.

The Department is not aware whether this equipment disappeared after arriving at Little Current or if, by oversight, your firm did not forward same. I shall be pleased if you will check up on this shipment and inform me if the full number of front and rear seats as ordered in letter above referred to were shipped.

As it is necessary that this equipment be supplied, I would request, if there was no oversight in shipping the previous order, that you forward by freight, charges prepaid, addressed to Geo. Dill, Esq., Teacher, Sucker Creek Indian Day School, Little Current, Ont., one No. 2 front and one No. 2 rear, of the same type as the other equipment which you supplied in July, last. They should be shipped knocked down, securely crated. Please forward your account, in triplicate, addressed to Mr. Dill. This account should cover the cost F.O.B. Little Current, sales tax included.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie
Secretary.

Globe Furniture Co. Ltd.,
Waterloo, Ont.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

You may think me all over the place. I only thought you shouldn't done anything about the seats concerning which I wrote you yesterday. I counted them today and in number they are alright. It is in size they made the mistake and so there is nothing to do.

Sorry to have made a fuss about nothing.

Yrs,

[Signature]
Ottawa, October 28, 1932.

Gentlemen:

Referring to our letter dated the 26th instant, regarding the No. 2 front and rear seats which were stated to be missing from the order supplied by you in July, last, for delivery at Little Current, Ont., I now have to inform you that, after a check up, the teacher informs us today that this equipment has been received. I regret any inconvenience that may have been caused your firm in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[F. MacKenzie, Secretary]

Globe Furniture Co. Ltd.,
Waterloo,
Ont.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Little Current, Ont.
November 25th 1932.

Dear Mr. Duthie:

When we ordered the chairs for Sucker Creek in July I wrote on the understanding that #2 was the small size. This was the size I really wanted two backs and 2 fronts for. I have discovered today that the small ones are #6. I am writing by this post to the manufacturers asking them to hold your new order for these until they hear from you again. Will you ask them to send the #6 instead of #2.

I am sorry to have created such a mix-up over these.

Yours truly,

George Hill
Indian Office, Manitowaning,
October 26th, 1932.

Sir:

With reference to Departmental Letter N. I9-4-5 of the 15th instant in regard to the request by the teacher at Sucker Creek School to have the interior of the school building repainted as the walls are in filthy condition; I have the honour to report that the interior walls and ceiling of this building are in a dismal condition and require renovating with paint. I estimate that the cost of having this work carried out will be approximately $38.00,-

4 gals. paint at $4.75 $19.00
Labour wash walls & ceiling 5.00
" painting, cleaning etc 14.00

The teacher is of the opinion that this work could be carried out on a week end and would not interfere with the regular classroom work to any extent, but as the walls require cleaning before they are painted, which will take some time, I believe that if the painting is authorized it would well to let the work stand until the Christmas holidays.

The old structure is hardly worth the expenditure but if maybe that this building will be made use of for some time, before it is replaced by a new school, I would recommend that the painting of the interior walls and ceiling be carried out, and the work to be performed by Indian labour.

Your obedient servant,

Indian agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 31, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the paint and labour in cleaning and painting the interior of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School building.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have this work carried out during the coming Christmas holidays. You should purchase the paint required and arrange for Indian labour in the cleaning of the walls and ceiling, and for the painting. You should see that the walls and ceiling are thoroughly clean and dry before the paint is applied, and you should see that a satisfactory job is performed.

After the work has been completed, please forward an account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the paint, also accounts, in triplicate, in favour of the Indians who perform the labour. The number of hours employed and the rate paid per hour should be stated in detail. The total expenditure should not exceed your estimate of approximately $35.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning,
Ont.

I have the honour to enclose herewith vouchers in favour of Mr. Oscar T. Bennett, of Little Current, and myself for paint supplies and payment made for labour in connection with the painting of the interior of the classrooms at the Nuthaw Creek Indian Day School:

Dear Mr. Buthland,

Since a new school at Sucker Creek Mills is impossible I am wondering if you can include sufficient funds in the Supplementary Estimates to cover:

1. A new floor - the present one is very uneven and cuts on the ground. Therein the living water comes through.

2. A new door.

3. Relining the roof. The roof leaks badly and I have to run the new paint.

Dear Sir:

Report on my inspection of the Manitowaning Agency on 11-13th ultimo.

The Sucker Creek Day School Church of England, is in a most dilapidated condition and totally unfit for school purposes. It was built in 1884 of log construction. The classroom is 20 x 25. Sixteen pupils on the roll and an average attendance of twelve. The classroom floor is worn out and has sunk nine inches in the centre. The walls and ceiling are dirty. The roof leaks badly. In wet weather the pupils have to move from place to place to keep out of the drip. The window frames, sills and foundations are rotten and have given way in places. The whole appearance of the building, outside and in, shows decay and neglect. No amount of repairs would put it in condition for school purposes. A new school is badly needed, it is only a matter of a very short time when the present structure will have to be abandoned.

(sgd) Thos McHookin,
Inspector.

A.S. Williams, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General,

Manitowaning, August 24th, 1934.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that the Sucker Creek Day School building is in a dilapidated condition, and beyond having repairs carried out to any advantage.

This building has been in use for over fifty years, and only a cheap construction when first built. The timber foundation has gone to pieces with age which has let the walls drop and effected the classroom floor to such an extent that it is not within a foot of being level.

The roof is in a leaky condition and will not stand to be re-shingled as the roof boarding is in such a state of deterioration that will not allow the old shingles to be removed without the whole roof being replaced.

As this building is in such a miserable condition, and totally unfit for any further use, and will have to be replaced by a new building as soon as possible, I cannot recommend that any extensive repairs be carried out to this old building but would recommend that a small expenditure not exceeding $10.00 be allowed in patching the roof for the time being.

Dear Sir:

On my recent visit to the Sucker Creek Indian Day School on the Manitoulin Island, I was disappointed to find into what a bad state it had got. The building is really in a deplorable condition, and the Chief told me that the band had resolved to close it. They cannot, of course, do this; but I simply mention the fact in order to show how discontented they have become with the school.

There are at present 14 children on the roll, and this number will be increased to 16 or 18 this fall, and they are expecting that there will probably be over 20 next year. This is the information which I got from our missionary and the Chief.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Manitowaning agency on the 24th-28th Oct.

Sucker Creek School is an old, dilapidated log building, 20' x 25' built 65 years ago as a mission church. There is seating accommodation for 20 pupils with 23 on the roll. Twelve or fifteen other children in the section are coming up to school age. For the year ended 31st March, 1937, the number on the roll was 16, and the average attendance of 12.

The building has become totally unfit for school purposes. No amount of repairs can make it suitable. The foundation, door and window frames are completely rotted away. The front part of the classroom floor is sunk 10 inches. In wet weather, mud springs up between the boards with every step.

On referring to file 19-4-5A, it will be seen the matter of providing a new school for this band has been under consideration for the past eight years. It has reached the stage now where parents state they will not allow the children to attend school during the winter months. Chief Obotossaway requests that steps be taken to close the school from Christmas to 1st April in the interest of the pupils' health. Under existing conditions, I can only add my recommendation to such action.

Thos. McGeekin,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Dear Sir:

A report has reached the Department indicating that the Sucker Creek Indian Day School is in bad condition and not worth repairing. I am further advised that a new site has been tentatively selected for a school on the Sucker Creek Reserve.

At the present time there are 2 or 3 former school buildings not in use. In this regard I refer particularly to the former Sheguinandah C.E. Day School.

Please secure the services of a contractor to advise you whether or not it would be possible to move this building to the proposed new site on the Sucker Creek Reserve and, if so, you should let me know what expenditure would be involved.

No special funds have been provided in the current year's appropriation for a new building at Sucker Creek but if the proposals mentioned above can be carried out at a reasonable figure an endeavour will be made to secure the necessary funds. An early reply would be appreciated.

Sir:

With reference to Official Letter No. 19-4-5 of the 10th of November last, in regard to having me secure the services of a contractor to advise me whether or not it would be possible to remove the Sheguinandah C.E. Day School to the proposed new site on the Sucker Creek Reserve, and if so, to advise me Department what expenditure would be involved; I have to report that this matter has been taken up with different contractors. They all advise me that the cost involved to move this building to Sucker Creek Reserve would compare with the cost of building a new school, as it would have to be demolished and the poor class of material in the construction of the building would be of little value in the building of another school.

I have made enquiries from the contractors if it would be possible to move the building without being demolished. They advise me that on account of the building being poorly constructed, a distance of twelve miles, narrow road between the two Reserves with several big hills it would be out of the question to make an attempt to move it without being wrecked.

On taking this matter up with the Chief at Sucker Creek on different occasions, he does not feel favourable towards an old building being moved on the Reserve. He states that they never had a habitable school building at Sucker Creek, and now they should have a new modern school similar to those the Department have built on other Reserves.

I might say for the information of the Department that after making an inspection of the school building at Sheguinandah I consider that the Department would not save any money to move it to Sucker Creek Reserve instead of erecting a new building, as the material is in a state of deterioration and only a small quantity would be of use in the construction of another building.

NAME OF BUILDING: Sucker Creek Indian Day School.

LOCATION: Sucker Creek Indian Reserve, Manitoulin Island Agency.

BRANCH: Indian Affairs

DATE: March 25th, 1939.

APPROPRIATION: $6,000

RECOMMEND CONSTRUCTION BY: BAY LABOUR

REASON: CLASS OF INDIAN DAY LABOUR AVAILABLE. For rough outside work.

BUILDING REQUIREMENTS: ROOMS AND ACCOMMODATION; NUMBER OF PUPILS; TYPE OF CONSTRUCTION.

Class-room and teacher's living quarters, with basement, cistern.

Class-room with two cloak-rooms. Living room, kitchen and bedroom in teacher's living quarters. Class-room should accommodate thirty-five pupils. Frame construction with concrete basement.

DESCRIPTION OF SITE AND CONDITIONS; SUBMIT PLAN; NORTH POINT; NATURE OF SOIL, DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS AND ANY OTHER PARTICULARS.

The proposed school site is composed of a portion of the East half of Lot number 14, con. 7, Sucker Creek Reserve, containing one acre. (Plan attached). It is high level ground, sand and clay soil with good drainage to the highway. Site is free of stone or rock.

WATER SUPPLY: SYSTEM REQUIRED; SOURCE OF WATER, ETC.

Cistern should be installed in basement for a supply for washing and cleaning purposes, and a well dug in the school yard for a supply of drinking water. Two hand pumps.
TOILET FACILITIES: SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM REQUIRED; LOCATION.

Three outside toilets would be required, one for the girl pupils, one for the boy pupils, and one for the teacher in school yard. The only means of sewage would be by pit or boxes that could be emptied.

HEATING SYSTEM: TYPE OF FURNACE OR BOILER; FUEL.

Hot Air Furnace should be installed in basement, wood fuel.

Wood stove in kitchen for cooking purposes.

LIGHTING SYSTEM: SOURCE OF POWER; SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS.

The only means of lighting building would be by oil lamps as there is not any electric power line in the reserve.

BUILT-IN EQUIPMENT REQUIRED: BLACKBOARD AREA; CUPBOARDS, ETC.

30 square feet of blackboard along one end of class-room. 20' x 4' side 15' x 4'.

Built-in cupboard in class-room for books and stationery.

Cupboard to be built in the kitchen of the teacher's living quarters. Sink should be installed in clothes closet in bed-room.

Hand pump should be installed in kitchen in order to get a supply of water from cistern to kitchen sink.

SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS FOR MATERIALS: NEAREST SHIPPING POINT

LOCAL TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES TO SITE, ETC.

Materials can be shipped by Railway to Little Current, or by boat during the summer months which call at all ports between Owen Sound and Sault Ste-Marie. Local transportation to site would be by trucks.

REMARKS:

A school with teacher's residence similar to the building erected in the Rabbit Island section of Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve during the last summer past would be suitable for the Sucker Creek Reserve.

Manitowaning, March 27th, 1939.

Sir:—

With reference to Official Letter No. I9-4-5 of the 23rd instant in regard to the necessity of providing a new school to replace the present Sucker Creek School, and it is hoped to be able to provide funds in the supplementary estimates for the erection of a new school on the Reserve, therefore, the Department enclosed data form for me to complete, I have the honour to enclose this form with definite answers to all questions.

The proposed site for this school is a suitable location. It contains one acre in the north west corner of the East half of Lot number 14, Con. 7, Sucker Creek Reserve. The soil is of sand and clay mixture, free from stone or rock, with good drainage for a basement.

No title has been obtained for this site, but I understand that the owner, William Mahtable, is agreeable to transfer it for a school site by being paid for the improvements as it is a portion of his farm, and he feels that he should receive some recompense for his work clearing the land.

The only means for a supply of water would be to have a cistern built in the basement with a pump in the kitchen on the teacher's living quarters for washing and cleaning purposes, and a well dug in the school yard for drinking water supply.

A building similar to the one built in the Rabbit Island section of Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve would be suitable for the Sucker Creek Reserve as there is approx. the same number of pupils to attend, and living quarters should be provided for the teacher as there is not any accommodation in the Reserve.

I estimate that a modern suitable school erected on Sucker Creek Reserve would cost $6,000.00.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I wish to make a report regarding the fencing of the new school site at Sucker Creek and also the question of water supply.

It would seem the opportune time to perform this work if funds are available while the contractor is at work there and the water would be very convenient while the building is in progress as there is no water very convenient to the work.

I expect water can be obtained at this school by digging about fifteen or twenty feet; and I would advise cribbing up with concrete cribbing. The cost will depend altogether on the depth and kind of soil we contact, but the cribbing costs $1.20 per foot; and I would judge with pump complete, the well would cost nearly $100.00.

The cost of fencing will be approximately the same with a ten strand fence of all No.9 wire and two gates, which is very necessary, to keep live stock from entering and having access to the school grounds, also, the farmers' crops adjoining the school site.

Sir:-

I wish to make a report on Sucker Creek School. The water has been seeping through the concrete walls of the basement making a nasty discoloration on the inside of walls and floor. I believe the chief cause for this, is the result of no eave troughs on the school, and the surrounding ground is high at the back and two sides of the school, which does not permit the surface water to get away, and consequently lies close to the building and seeps in.

I have gotten an estimate from John King, Indian tinsmith at Manitowaning on the eave troughing, and I imagine if thirty dollars were spent in banking the building a little more, and levelling off the grounds, the water could be kept away from the building, thereby eliminating most of this trouble.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Indian Day School,
Sucker Creek Reserve, Ontario.

With reference to your memorandum of the 16th instant covering a report from Indian Agent C.R. Johnston on the above, it is noted that the interior wall and floor finish in the basement is being discoloured apparently by the seepage of water through the concrete walls.

In this connection I may say that drainage tile was provided around the walls and under the floor slab of this building, and the exterior surface of the basement walls, below grade, were waterproofed with two coats of hot coal tar pitch. Under normal circumstances there should be no seepage through the foundation walls, and since Mr. Johnston's report does not state the location or extent of the leakage it is difficult to determine the cause of the trouble.

It may be possible, however, that the earth fill around the building has settled, creating the depression described by Mr. Johnston, which would allow roof and surface water to lie close to the building. The site generally is flat as shown by photographs submitted to you under cover of my memorandum of November 3rd, 1939. Any settlement of fill should be corrected and sufficient banking provided to raise the grade line at the building high enough to produce a fall away from the foundation walls.

No eavestroughing was provided in the contract for this school. Regarding the suggestion that eavestrough would prevent water from entering the building, it should be realized that unless the downspouts were connected to a vitrified tile drain and conveyed to a sump, some distance from the building they would be of little value. Further, in view of winter ice conditions prevailing in the vicinity, damage to eavestroughing would be frequent and maintenance costly.

Under the circumstances, it is felt that the contractor for this work should be requested to report regarding the cause of the trouble before any work is undertaken by the Department. We propose therefore to request Harper Brothers, Little Current, Ontario, to investigate the matter and to report on the situation as soon as possible.

I shall be pleased to advise you further regarding the matter as soon as this report is received.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

Extract from Inspector Geiger's report on the Sucker Creek Indian Day School visited on April 28, 1942.

The children are comfortably housed. The seats have been turned to face the back of the room for conveniences in church services. It may serve this purpose well but it causes light to fall from the children's right, hence I cannot approve same.

The school is clean and good housekeeping meets the eye. The outside toilets should have the floors scrubbed now that the muddy season is over. In general the property shows good care. The well serves the needs at present but I understand goes dry later in the season.

The lawn in front requires some attention. Flower beds are planned for, and a few trees will be planted. No attempt has been made to arrange for a school garden.
Ottawa,
May 23, 1942.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Sucker Creek School on April 28, Inspector Geiger writes as follows:

"The children are comfortably housed. The seats have been turned to face the back of the room for conveniences in church services. It may serve this purpose well but it causes light to fall from the children's right, hence I cannot approve same."

This building is primarily intended for school purposes and not for church purposes. Consequently, the seats should be so arranged that the light falls over the left shoulders of the children during school hours. If the seats were attached to wooden runners they could be turned when church services are being held in the building. We have no objection to the Indians using the building for church purposes, but the Department must insist that the use of the building in this manner does not interfere with the school work.

The Inspector recommends that the floors of the toilets be scrubbed as the muddy season is now over. He also states that the lawn in front of the school requires some attention. To carry out these recommendations will not involve any heavy expenditure and you should arrange to have them done at once.

Yours truly,

Mr. C.R. Johnston,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I am in receipt of your letter dated October 31st File No. 19-4-5, in reference to my voucher No. 42-474 amounting to $25.00, for payments made by me for cleaning Sucker Creek School.

I had no idea it would cost so much to clean the place up, as I estimated the total cost at $25.00, and the cleaning alone cost $25.00, but they went over the whole building from attic to basement and done a good job. February 25, 1943

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

As you are aware Anglican Church Services are being held in the school house at Sucker Creek Reserve owing to their church building being unfit for the purpose, and the parish cannot afford to build a new church at the present time.

The Minister, Cannon Haines of Little Current, who is in charge, has approached me in regard to having the bell from the old church installed at the school house, either on the school, or outside, separate from the school.

As there is no bell on either of the new schools in this Agency, it has occurred to me that possibly it is not the policy of the Department to install bells on their schools, and would therefore prefer to have your advice on the matter.

There is a very good bell on the old church, and will you please advise if there is any objection to having it installed at the school, and whether the Department would bear any or all the expense in connection, as it could also be used for school purposes.

C. R. Johnston
Indian Agent
Ottawa,

In any case we do not see any necessity for moving the bell as suggested in your letter.

Mr. G.R. Johnston, Indian Agent, Manitowaning, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, the Department approves the purchase of the articles shown on the attached list, with the exception of an expenditure for manual training supplies. This will mean that the cost of the articles will be approximately $35.

Philip Phalan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to report a few repairs are required at Sucker Creek School.

The Inspector has commented that there is no flag pole at this school. I have requisitioned for the necessary rope and pulley, and would ask to have a flag included and sent from Ottawa for this school.

The purchase of a pole, and cost of erection is estimated at $15.00 and will be supplied by the Indians.

The two outside toilets should be moved as the pits are caving in allowing the toilets to tip over. The doors also need replacing, which altogether will cost about $30.00 for the two toilets.

The teacher has asked to have the floors thoroughly scrubbed and oiled before opening of school, and there should be more gravel applied outside both school entrances. The clay soil tracks in the school badly in wet weather.

There is, I believe sufficient oil on hand for the floors, and I would estimate the cost of labour for scrubbing and oiling floors, and hauling gravel at $30.00, making a total expenditure of $75.00. I would be glad to have an advance cheque of $70.00 to pay for labour at your earliest convenience.

ORJ / JH

Indian Agent

I enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for Sucker Creek School.

Mrs. McLeod informed me just prior to opening of the school at September 1st that she wanted the living quarters washed and painted before opening of school, and I had not time then, to requisition for the paint etc. She also complained that the Indian woman I employed the year before did a poor job, so I instructed her to employ two whitemen to do the work.

The paint and two brushes were obtained at Little Current from A. J. Smith and Kingsboro and Baxter. The quotations on other supplies were secured from S. W. McPhee & Co., C. W. Hinds and Eaton's Catalogue.

The cost of labour for washing walls and ceilings, and painting amounts to $50.00.

I would suggest approval of this work as it was badly needed. I would recommend local purchase of the other supplies, with the exception of crayons, and brushes for water colours, which could possibly be supplied from Ottawa, as they are not obtainable locally.

C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent

Sir,

In reply to your favor of the 21st instant requesting a report on the lack of educational facilities for the education of the children at the Temagamingue Reserve, I wish to say that owing to the inaccessible position of the Temagamingue Reserve, located as it is about forty-five miles west of Lake Temiscamingue, only reached by traversing a succession of small streams and lakes, I do not think it would be possible to establish or maintain a school at this Reserve, as it would be very difficult to get a white teacher to remain there.

The influence of the Hudson's Bay Co., around whose post on Bear Island in Lake Temiscamingue the houses of the members of this band are clustered, is one which tends to slightly educate the Indians belonging to the Temagamingue Band, but until more easy access with the outside world is made possible I do not see how educational matters at this Reserve can be improved.

P.S. The number of children of school age at Temagamingue is 17.

Your obedient servant,

W.B. Maclean

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In reply to your enquiry as to the necessity for a school for the Temagami Indians, I beg to say that Mr Agent McLean in his last Annual Report states that the population of this band is about 86, about 20 of whom are children of school age for whom no educational facilities are as yet provided.

The question of establishing a school for these Indians has been before the Department for several years but owing to no reserve having been allotted to this band and their unsettled habits, the Department did not consider it practicable to establish a school for them.

In Sept. '02 the Deputy Minister of Education for Ontario forwarded a petition for the establishment of a school on Bear Island where most of these Indians reside. Mr Agent McLean was asked for a special report on this petition and in replying he stated that while he was quite in accord with the tenor of the petition if it were practical to establish and maintain a school on Bear Island, he pointed out that there were difficulties in the way which would, he thought, prevent the project from being carried out. He called attention to the difficulty there would be in securing a teacher to go there the frequent absence of the Indians for prolonged
periods while hunting; and also to the fact that a considerable number of the Temagami Indians do not reside permanently at Bear Island, but live at White Bear Lake about 20 miles distant.

These Indians, Mr McLean says, are bright and intelligent, but until they are permanently settled I do not see how the Department can undertake to establish a school for them.

A church is in course of erection near the Hudson's Bay post but the Agent says he does not see how services are to be conducted, except at long intervals. In case the Roman Catholics place a missionary permanently in charge there, the Department might contribute something towards the education of the children, provided he is willing to teach them while they are in the neighborhood of the mission. I do not see that we could grant a fixed annual salary as teaching could only be undertaken at irregular intervals.

Dear Sir:—

In reply to your letter of the 16th. inst. I am directed by the Minister of Education to suggest that owing to the migratory habits of our northern Indian people, the erection of a permanent school building would scarcely be warranted. In no case does the Department of Education give grants for building purposes.

Would not a camp school answer the immediate necessities of the case? A suitable tent could be provided by the Federal Government, and its equipment and maintenance for the Spring, Summer, and early Fall would not be a great expense.

I understand that in other parts of Canada provision is made by the Dominion Government for grants to various organizations for the education of its wards. Would not the case of the Temagami Indians, who are on an Indian Reservation, under the control of your Government, come under your general provisions? Dear Sir,

Your letter received asking me to give a report of the general progress of the school at Bear Island. The attendance for the months of July and August was very satisfactory; there being
an average of about seventeen pupils daily. We discovered one difficulty in encouraging all the children in the district to go to school every day. Some would be found loitering around their tents and neglecting their education.

The total number on the register was twenty seven—the majority of whom were males. Ten of this number were very irregular—much owing to the fact that their parents
were constantly changing their camps. Even, however, when they were with in the school section their parents did not give them much encouragement in regard to their education.

Generally speaking the progress of those who attended regularly was good. The grades ranged from "one" to "four"—most of whom were in the first two (grades). Some of these children showed signs of more than ordinary
ability, for, considering the opportunities afforded them, this fact could be clearly seen.

I trust this brief report will meet with your approval, and if my work has been satisfactory I would be glad to accept the same position for the next term.

My Dear Mr. Cockburn,

I just received a letter from Bear Island, asking me whether or not Miss Horan is going to teach the school there next summer. The same party adds that he is wishing for a change; & I know that his reasons are very good.

On my part, I am of opinion that such Miss Horan is doing more harm than good there, the way she behaves, putting her nose where she has no business; & I wish more than any body else for her quick change.

I am speaking here in my quality of pastor appointed there by the Bishop to look after the spiritual welfare of the community, & my few years experience there have convinced me simply that such Miss Horan is undesirable, & I strongly wish for her removal.

Have you got any good teacher at all to put in her place? To speak more clearly,
I am sick of her, & I am not the only one to say so.

I will explain myself more clearly when I have a chance to see you.

In the meantime, I hope you will not renew any engagement with her till we have a chance to discuss the matter over.

There was a Mrs. Gould there some three years ago. She was number one. But just on that account she did not please the Turner's click. I wish we could get that Lady again. I could wish for no better.

Yours very Truly

I have been much surprised to hear that the teacher lady, Miss Mary Honan, who has been for many years so devoted, kind and successful, I may say in her duty, at Bear Island, Tingamini, has not been accepted for next season. Dear Sir,

Your favour of the 6th instant received and noted.
As you advised in said letter I again offer my services as teacher for the Bear Island Summer School for the term beginning May 1, 1929. I ask for a salary of $90 per month and if practicable a term of six months teaching.

You know no matter how economical a teacher may be, in this age, no one could provide for seven months unemployed on five months salary of $85 per month, besides it is an expensive trip to and from Bear Island here and board there is $1 a day.

Respectfully yours,

This is to let you know that I am at Bear Island for the third time this summer; and I have the pleasure to tell you that the Indian School, which I visited every time, has been attended more than ever; it is a good note for the teacher, Miss M. Dermott, who is kind to the children, which are making good progress also.

I think that the school could be opened yet during the month of October; the teacher is willing to stay, and pupils in number—Do, if it is agreeable to your Dept., let it know, by writing to Miss M. Dermott.

I am coming back from Wolf Lake where the school has been built, and closed opened under the direction of Miss Cath. M. Ryan, who, I hope, will succeed well—In a few days I will make my report—Yours truly, Missionary P.S.

Dear Mr. Cockburn,

Regarding the Bear Island Summer School I am not asking the Department to give me the position as teacher there for the term beginning May 1, 1931. There was a feeling amongst some of the people last term in which perhaps they are fully justified, that I am too old for the place.

Without the good will of all the parents I could not keep the school up to the high level that I kept it for the terms of 1928, 1929 and 1930. For this reason I do not want to go back to work amongst the Bear Island Indians for the summer of 1931.

Should the Department be willing to place me in some other Indian School I consider that I could give good service for another year.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

I have your memo of the 12th instant, with letter attached from the Honourable Mr. Finlayson, Minister of Lands and Forests for Ontario, suggesting the establishment of a school to be conducted during the entire school year at Bear Island, Lake Temagami.

In this connection I have to say that, during the past number of years, a school was conducted at this point from May first to September 30th - a five month period, each year. Last summer, during the period the school was open, there was an enrolment of 34 children, with an average attendance of 27.

Mr. George P. Cockburn, Sturgeon Falls, the local Indian Agent, was requested, in April, last, to state whether, in his opinion, the school should be conducted this summer or not. In replying, he stated he considered the opening of the school for the present spring and summer months could be dispensed with, in the interests of effecting a saving in expenditure. Our Vote has been so extremely reduced, that it is necessary to discontinue a number of summer schools this year, and Agent Cockburn was advised that the Bear Island School would not be re-opened.

Formerly, the Indians at this point were at Bear Island only during the summer months, going to
their hunting grounds in the fall and winter. As the hunting is gradually becoming exhausted, the Indians are more and more remaining the entire year at Bear Island.

There are no funds this year for the establishment of a permanent school. The question of a year-round school will, in view of the number of Indian children now located at this point, receive consideration and the amount required for the salary of a teacher and other current expenses, if possible, be provided in our Estimates for the next fiscal year.

I would beg to suggest that Mr. Finlayson be advised that the question of conducting a permanent school will receive consideration but that, for the present fiscal year, there are no funds to pay the salary of a teacher and other expenses. Mr. Finlayson's letter is being returned herewith, as requested.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

I beg to state that during the latter half of 1934 and early in 1935 an attempt was made through the local Public School Inspector, Mr. P.W. Brown, B.A., of North Bay, to open a Public School on Bear Island. Mr. Brown formed the School Section and the formation received the official approval of this Department.

It seems, however, that there is some doubt as to whether the residents desire a Public School or a Separate School. It will be impossible to maintain two schools.

It would be quite possible if most of the parents concerned are Roman Catholics to open the school as a Public School and to engage a teacher of Roman Catholic faith if the board of trustees so desires. It would not be possible, however, to have religious instruction given during school hours if the school were a Public School. The Regulations for Public Schools would permit the giving of this instruction before or after school hours only.

It would be quite possible, if the people so desire, to organize a Separate School in accordance with the Separate Schools Act. Please see Sections 18, 19 and 20, of the Separate Schools Act, a copy of which is being sent to you under separate cover.

I have to refer to my memorandum dated February 14th, last, regarding the operation of a summer school at Bear Island, Lake Temagami, Nipissing Indian Agency, Ont., (Federal District of Temiskaming South). This school is not located on a Reserve.

I should be pleased to be advised if you approve of this school being conducted during the coming summer months - for the period from May 1st to September 30th, next. If you approve, I should appreciate your directions regarding the teacher to be employed. These Indians are all Roman Catholic, and it would be necessary to engage the services of a teacher of that denomination.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MR. MCGILL:

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department desires to reopen the summer school at Bear Island, Lake Temagami. Mrs. M. Thibault, Haileybury, Ont., has been appointed teacher. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $85 per teaching month.

The Department would like this school to reopen as soon as possible after the first of May, next. I would request that you inform Mrs. Thibault and arrange with her to take up duties. This school should be conducted during the coming summer from, approximately, May first to September 30th.

If any classroom supplies are required, a requisition should be forwarded.

Please give Mrs. Thibault any assistance you can as she commences duties, and you should advise the Department the exact date on which the school opened. Please give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir:

For years His Majesty's Canadian Government placed someone in charge of the school-house here, and was paid the sum of $20.00 a year. William Pishato, now a very old man and destitute, looked after this for 12 years after Old John Turner died 13 years ago. It was always that way until Mr. J.A. Marleau became Indian Agent. It was then stated that if any repair work was to be done to the school, this was to be paid separately, and the bill to be sent to the Indian Agent. I would like to know, as chief, why the said Indian Agent has cut this off, as he has done with most everything.

Take the old and destitute people for example. They get only $4.84 a month to live. I would ask you who could possibly live on such a pittance. Please let me hear from you at your earliest, and believe me to remain,

Yours faithfully,

The Nipissing Indians are not now attending the Garden Village Day School. Thirty-six (36) are going to public and separate schools in Sturgeon Falls and 14 are attending classes in North Bay. The Director,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada:

Dear Sir:

For the past three years I have been employed by your department as teacher and medical attendant on the Bear Island Indian Reservation, near Temagami, Ontario.

I am now looking for permanent work, and I was wondering what you might have to offer.

I am bilingual and have completed five years of University work. I graduated in 1944 from the University of Western Ontario with an honor Bachelor of Arts degree in philosophy and psychology. Last spring I completed two years of the medical course, which were essentially two years of science. I have also done post-graduate work in psychology, this comprising courses in mental testing, personnel management, clinical methods, experimental problems. Due to financial difficulties I am forced to discontinue my studies.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am writing concerning the Indian Day School opened each summer for the Indian children of the Bear Island Reserve in this Sturgeon Falls Agency.

For the past three summers I have been employed by your department as teacher and medical attendant for the island. As the only resident representative of the Department, my duties have been many and varied, and oftentimes onerous. I have been called upon to settle everything from family quarrels to epidemics. I have always tried to give a full measure of satisfaction.

My purpose in writing is to seek a more satisfactory adjustment in my salary. I have been re-appointed to the task for this coming summer, and I am grateful for your continued confidence in me. At the same time, my summer earnings are very necessary for the continuance of my medical course. I have had to secure leave of absence from University this year because I could not make enough during the past summer.

Because of lack of living quarters, I have had to rent a cabin in which to live while on the Island. Food prices are exceptionally high because of the extra water transportation. These combined with other factors tend appreciably to reduce my net savings.

May I further mention that my training in applied psychology has enabled me to work with the Indians with a minimum of friction. My medical training has cut down appreciably the work of the Indian doctor, Dr. Arnold. In fact, the times I have sought his aid have been few.

I am at present employed by the H.E.F.C., at La cave, as camp purchasing agent and doctor. They are paying me $236.00 per month. I shall be very pleased to return to Bear Island this summer and for the next 4 or 5 summers, if you can make the position more attractive, financially.

Yours very sincerely,

Thos. A. McGuire, B.A.

Dear Sir,

Your unlocked for letter of Oct. 21st was duly received and contents noted. Many thanks for same.

May say am not now expecting any special consideration from Dept. of Indian Affairs since my application for a position in an Indian Day School was overlooked when a vacancy occurred on a nearby Reserve to Sudbury beginning of current year and preference was given a teacher who had only served Dept. a few terms.

Another injustice: When placed in charge of Bear Island School spring of 1928 was advised Term would be from May 1st, condition that teacher should be ready to go to the Island soon as possible after navigation opened on Lake Temagami. I rushed up spring of 1929 found no regular boat making daily trip was obliged to hire special for which I paid $10. Enclosed please find receipt for same.

It was a well known fact that navigation on Lake Temagami was late spring of 1930. Was advised Navigation Co. sent first boat to Bear Island Sat. May 11th, second boat May 15th I arrived at Temagami next day found no boat making the trip that day and was again obliged to hire a special launch.
Trust you see that it was practicably impossible for me to have opened school less one day sooner than I did. Yet when I received my pay Cheque my salary for said month was curtailed $42.50.

Doubtless such treatment had never been meted a teacher in the history of the Bear Island School and it was my twenty-first year in the service of the Department.

Again thanking you for your letter

I am,

Most respectfully yours,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant Rev. H. A. O'Neill should forward a return each month showing the names of the pupils, days taught etc. As soon as this is received his cheque will be issued.

Figure 2 shows the desk both top and seat extended to full height. Either desk top, or the back and seat, can be adjusted to desired height independently of each other.

Note in standard the heads of two bolts. The bolts are for the purpose of clamping parts together. There is a main upright standard fitted with grooves, in which run the lugs or projections on castings of the desk top, also back and seat.

To raise or lower the desk top, loosen top bolt on each standard (right and left) and adjust the top to desired height. Then secure bolts tightly and everything is as secure as though made in one piece, owing to the peculiar construction of the grooves or corresponding lugs, or projections, spoken of before. The back and seat adjust together, that is, they raise and lower together. To make adjustment, loosen lower bolts on standards, adjust to desired height, fasten the bolts, thereby clamping parts together, and everything is accomplished securely and well.

An important item. As desk top is lowered, it moves on an incline, bringing it closer to the occupant of the accompanying seat. The seat and back also works the same way, i.e., as it is lowered it moves on an incline, bringing it closer to the desk in front. A necessary and very important feature, and to be found only in our Adjustable Desk.

Study this point well. The ordinary adjustable desk simply moves up and down in a vertical way. To adjust a desk and seat properly it is just as important that their relative distance should be changed as their height should be changed. A small pupil requires less room than a large one and the seat should consequently be closer to the desk and vice versa.

Figure 3 shows desk top lowered for the pupil using it, while the seat in front for a larger pupil is raised to full height. This, of course, could be reversed, the desk at a high point for a large pupil and the seat in front lowered for a smaller pupil.

Our Patent Measuring Gauge

The illustrations show our measuring gauge in various forms. In figure 4 we give merely a sectional view showing working parts. 'A' represents main standard, which as you will see in another illustration, is firmly fastened to a metal base which enables the gauge to stand alone, which is a very great convenience in adjusting desks.

'B' is a supplementary standard which, by means of cog wheels inside of casting (E), is raised or lowered as the arm (C) is adjusted to size of pupil. When the arm (C) is adjusted to proper height the top of standard B is the proper height for lower edge of desk top.

'C' is the arm by which measurements are taken. The pupil sits in chair with feet resting on floor. Measurement is taken on lower side of pupil's limb just behind the knees as shown in figure 7. When measurement is ascertained the outer edge of seat should be the height indicated by height of arm C. The height of the desk for the pupil measured should be that indicated by the extreme height of standard B, measuring the lower edge of desk lid.

'D' is a thumb screw which holds the gauge in position while the desk is being adjusted.

'E' is a metal frame containing cog wheels which turn on cogs in standards A and B. The arrangement of these wheels is such that standard B is raised 1¼ inches for every inch that arm C is raised, that is, for every inch that the seat is raised or lowered the desk top should be correspondingly raised or lowered 1¼ inches.

In figure 5, we show gauge extended almost to its full height as it stands on floor when measuring. Figure 5 shows gauge folded compactly for pupil's use. Folds in this way it occupies a space of 18 x 3 inches, which readily admits of its being placed in teacher's desk and kept under lock and key free from the reach of mischievous boys. This is the only gauge that folds compactly, permitting it to be securely put away in an ordinary drawer. Other gauges are unwieldy affairs, unsuited in every way for the purpose for which they were intended, awkward to handle and difficult to understand. Our gauge is compact, convenient to use, and so simple that any one can adjust desks perfectly without any extended explanations, which are necessary with other gauges and which none but an expert can understand.

The Use of a Measuring Gauge

The use of a measuring gauge is an indispensable adjunct to adjustable desks. Without it the adjustment of desks is mere guess work and, moreover, it is much more convenient to use the gauge. Without the gauge the desk and seat must be adjusted without opening the same, which is very inconvenient, as the work must then be done in school house, creating much confusion and inconvenience. With a gauge the teacher goes through the room taking the measurement of each pupil, as shown in figure 7. The teacher makes a record of the size of each pupil, which she hands to the janitor and, after school hours, he takes the list of measurements and, with our patent measuring gauge, adjusts each seat and desk, as shown in figures 8 and 9, at a proper height from the floor, something which is utterly impossible to do without the use of our gauge.

Do not for a moment consider the purchase of adjustable desks that are not adjusted by means of the measuring gauge. An adjustable desk without a gauge is of about as much use as would be a wagon without wheels.

Adjustable desks should be in use in every school room where there is any regard for health, but an adjustable desk that is not adjustable by means of a gauge, thereby insuring its being automatically correct, is a delusion and a sham and should be avoided. An incorrect adjustment is bad or worse than no adjustment at all. Our gauge is our own device and can not be had with any other desks but those made by us. It is endorsed by the leading physicians as being anatomically correct and with its use desks are perfectly adjusted to fit the pupil.
Adjustment of "Ball-Bearing" Combination Adjustable Desk

Figure 7 shows a pupil occupying desk and teacher taking proper measurement for adjustment. As explained elsewhere when gauge arm is adjusted to proper height for seat, the top of gauge is the height for the edge of desk next to pupil.

The teacher takes the measurement (taking but an instant for each pupil) and makes record of proper adjustments. After school hours the janitor makes adjustment according to the measurement given him.

In all other adjustable desks operated without a measuring gauge, desk must be adjusted during school hours with pupil occupying it, a very inconvenient arrangement, creating untold confusion and inconvenience. Moreover, without a gauge the adjustment is merely guess work. With our gauge the adjustment is anatomically correct. No confusion in school hours, no distraction from studies.

Figure 8 shows janitor adjusting top of desk. Observe that the lid is on a level with top of gauge. The adjustment may be supposed to have been made and he is tightening bolts, clamping upright standard and desk top castings together. When bolts are loosened the top may be moved up and down very easily, but when they are tightened the castings are as securely fastened and as rigid as though cast in one piece. Note that for desk top adjustment, the top bolts are operated—one on each standard (right and left).
Figure 9 shows a janitor adjusting back and seat. The back and seat raise or lower together and by releasing the lower bolts on standards (right and left) the adjustment can be easily made by raising or lowering the back as shown in cut.

After proper adjustment is made, tighten bolts securely and the parts are practically one piece. They cannot be moved or changed from the position in which they are locked without unlocking the bolts, no matter what pressure is brought to bear.

This is a question that is not by any means as simple as it may seem on the surface, by reason of the endless variety of natural conditions that must be taken into account in order to determine what bell is best adapted to the particular requirements of each individual case. We recommend the purchase of a superior cast-steel bell only when the circumstances demand it; and do not do so from merely mercenary considerations, but from a long, practical experience gained through many years of observation.

We have found that there are possibilities for small churches, particularly the case with church bells, in which we have had occasion to supply. In such cases, the demand is usually for a small bell, and not for the large, heavy bells required by the larger churches.

The superiority of our cast-steel bells is evident from the fact that they are more durable than any other type of bell. They are also less expensive than other types of bells, and require less maintenance.

The lasting power of our bells will amply justify their purchase, and before making what is expected to be a permanent investment, the church should consider the following points:

1. The size of the bell is determined by the size of the church and the number of people who attend services.

2. The weight of the bell is determined by the size of the church and the number of people who attend services.

3. The quality of the bell is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

4. The price of the bell is determined by the size of the church and the number of people who attend services.

5. The durability of the bell is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

6. The maintenance of the bell is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

7. The appearance of the bell is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

8. The sound of the bell is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

9. The cost of the bell is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

10. The satisfaction of the customer is determined by the quality of the materials used in its manufacture.

The above points should be considered before purchasing a bell.

We do not work by guess, and with our long experience as bell-founders cannot be tempted to take chances. A bell that comes safely through the first month of its use successfully has given a hopeful promise of endurance, while in one that has lasted a year the chances of breaking are so trifling as to scarcely be taken into account. As our warranty follows every stroke of one of our bells for five years, the question of any risk whatever in buying one of our superior cast-steel bells is entirely removed.

School Bells.

As an unfailing incitement to punctuality, a stimulus to the naturally prompt, an efficient urge to the tardy, the school bell cannot be overrated, and in this particular no clock can approach it in efficiency. What the ship's bell is to the crew of a well-ordered vessel, the school bell is to the "crew" when it assembles; and its ringing at regular intervals, especially in rural districts, is a recognized force on the side of punctuality. Clocks constantly vary—many do not strike, and little children cannot tell the time by them; but when the peal of the well-known bell rings out, big and little, young and older, all set their faces schoolward, and punctuality becomes the rule and not the exception. In villages, or where the population is more or less scattered, the value of a lively, far-reaching bell upon the school-house cannot be overestimated, and for such service nothing can be had better than one of our superior cast-steel bells.

How Far Can a Bell be Heard?

This is, of course, a very important question, but one to which a general answer only can be made, as the natural conditions governing the transmission of sound must vary in every case. In a hilly or rolling country a bell cannot be heard half as far as on a plain or flat district. Sound will travel much further up and down
A valley than over the hill range that enclose such valley. Where the regular belfry or room, in which the bell is hung is lower than surrounding buildings or groves of trees, its sound will be greatly circumscribed. Frequently bells have but small window- or openings and inside the lower boards so close together as to almost stifle the sound those very openings were designed to send abroad. Bells can be heard for a long distance across lakes or sheets of water, but it is a popular error to conclude that the distance a bell can be heard is exclusively a question of weight, and that a bell weighing 1000 pounds can be heard twice as far as one of 500 pounds. The large bell does not furnish anything like double the resonant surface of the smaller one, and, of course, the volume of sound is greatly diminished by such surface. As has already been noted, in the large bell we gain those deep, solemn tones which are impossible in smaller ones; but from small bells, with their sharp, penetrating tones, great sound-carrying power is attainable. A small bell hung out of all just proportion to the performance of a 1000-pound bell in a church-tower comparatively close at hand, and such instances constantly lead to unfair comparison. A sharp, shrill sound penetrates to a long distance; when shrill noise is demanded, but when the quality of that shrilling tone be loud, then enchantment cannot be borne from distance. Great sound-spreaders, decidedly a large bell, as without fire and consequent weight, these features are quite unattainable. When bells are stationary, and struck or tolled, they will not, as a rule, be heard half as far as when rung by swinging, for the reason that the swinging motion, by constantly throbbing the mouth of the bell upward, scatters its tones far abroad, and at the same time superior to those tones a fixed bell.

Agreement made in duplicate the 25th day of June A.D. 1909.

Between His Majesty King Edward the Seventh, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And George Sutherland of the village of Sturgeon Falls, District of Nipissing, Province of Ontario.

(hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame school-house on stone foundation which is to be erected on Bear Island Temagami Ontario according to plans and specifications prepared for the same by the Department of Indian Affairs and being numbered 193.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the first day of October A.D. 1909.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of One Thousand four hundred and forty dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the said Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, acting as aforesaid, and the said George Sutherland have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above mentioned.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant enclosing a communication sent you by the Presbyterian Missionary at Bear Island applying for permission to hold services in the school building at that place.

In reply I beg to say that the Department would like to have a special report from you on this application. I may state that it does not approve of school buildings being used for other than school purposes as a general thing. In this instance, as the Indians for whom the school was put up are Roman Catholics, it is a question whether it would be advisable to grant the Missionary's request.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Geo. F. Cockburn, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sturgeon Falls, Ont.
Dear sir,

I am just after having a consultation with a person who has received the information from your department that the possibility of the Presbyterian missionary receiving permission to hold services in the school house is at least doubtful. Now, sir, I desire to say a few words on this subject.

Now, to come to the point you desire further particulars before you can grant permission. These particulars sir, I will give you. I am here representing the Presbyterian church in Canada. I have the welfare of my country at heart. I am here to teach neither dogma nor creed; but am, to instil into the minds of these people a high conception of citizenship. Candidly, I was surprised to receive such a letter from this department.
I am here to teach men to be worthy of the name Canadian. The schoolhouse has been placed here by the Canadian government for educational purposes. It is an institution which aims essentially at development in every sense. What reasons you may have against me holding a service there once a week is something that I am unable to comprehend. What is it that the Indians don't desire it? This because the Indians don't desire it? This is no argument and is not a fact at any rate. I am sure in saying that there is no rational argument that can stand against it. Since I am a student—since I have come here for the summer to work for both church and state and I at least expected that I would have the government of my country to back me up. I was perfectly willing to request your permission that is business, but when it comes to you asking for further particulars I am at a loss to find reasons for your action in this particular connection. This act is essential and must be done by a Christian statesman. I shall not desist from my work here even if I have to hold often
I am grieved to think that the Dominion Government refused to make up of the greatest citizens in Ireland should fail me in this request—not only this but belittle my work in the eyes of the people both permanent residents and tourists from the United States. Sir, I must investigate the matter and if you have valid reasons for hesitation ("further particulars") a blank refusal or am waiting to consider them shall however obey you and hold my meeting elsewhere during the summer—even though I had installed an agen in the school house and made all necessary arrangement believing that my request would be favourably considered.

I remain

Your obedient servant,

I beg to inform you that an application was forwarded to our agent at Sturgeon Falls from Mr T.R.McGillivray, Presbyterian Missionary at Bear Island for permission to hold services in the school house there.

The Department questioned the advisability of allowing protestant services to be held in a Roman Catholic school and before dealing with the application our agent was asked for a special report for the following reasons:

All the Indians of the Temagami band at Bear Island are shown by the census returns to be Roman Catholics. The building was put up and the school opened at the request of the Roman Catholic Mission and it has always been in charge of a teacher of that denomination.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter received from Mr McGillivray regarding his application and beg to say that he has been told that the matter has been referred to you and that the Department will await your reply before giving a final decision.

Sir,

I beg to report that the stone foundation of the Bear Island Summer school building owing to the frost last winter is not in good condition; the same happened three years ago when it was then repaired. It appears that the ground in that vicinity has a number of springs of water. The Hudson's Bay Company recently erected a new store building which has been affected in the same manner. I think if the building was placed upon cedar posts it would overcome the difficulty created by the frost during the winter. The platform and steps outside of the building also require replacing. The work could be done by resident labour and Indians and would cost about $175.00.

Your Obedient Servant

[Signature]

Ottawa, June 12, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, informing the Department of the repairs which will be necessary to the foundation of the Bear Island Summer School building, and furnishing an estimate of the cost of having the work done.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have cedar posts of the requisite dimensions put under the building to replace the present stone foundation which has been damaged by frost. It is thought that if the work of putting the cedar posts under the building is completed satisfactorily, it will to a very large extent overcome the difficulty which has been experienced through the heaving of the stone foundation by frost. This work should be carried out by day labour - Indians being employed as far as possible. Proper time sheets in duplicate should be kept for all labour employed. These should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department, in order that payment can be made.

It is hoped that the Indians will be able to supply the cedar posts, but, if not, please arrange for the purchase of the quantity and sizes required and forward properly certified vouchers in duplicate covering the expenditure incurred for the purpose.

No unnecessary expense should be incurred in having the above authorized work carried out. The cost should not exceed your estimate of $175 and should be lower, if possible. You may arrange to have the work done as soon as convenient.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

On August 22nd I inspected the Bear Island Seasonal School and found that it is badly in need of repair. Two years ago I sent an estimate of $350.00 to the Department which I believed would be necessary to make the above repairs, but have not been advised to proceed.
