Dear Mr. Little,

I have been after the agent and the chief of Indian affairs for the last four or five years, to get the school here repaired, which it need fixing very badly. I even wrote to the minister of Indian affairs, with that, did not do any good. The agent, Mr. Marley, said to us here last summer the school here does not belong to Indians, maybe that is the reason the Indian affairs don't want it repaired. Whoever belongs to the school should let it repaired before it falls apart. We have now loose the best teacher we ever have on account of the condition of the School here. The roof is torn and leaks badly, veranda is broken up, the foundation is rotten, on the outside it's all water and mud. I would very much if you would ask the school inspector, or some officials of the school board to come and investigate to see for yourself.
the condition of the school here. We cannot do anything with Indian agent or the Dept of Indian affairs, to see the school repaired, it is too bad to let it stand the way it is as it is a very good building, something should be done about it without any further delay, with kindest regards.

Sincerely yours,

Chief John Truain

Sturgeon Falls, April 23, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Bear Island School.

In reply to your letter of April 11, concerning repairs to Bear Island Seasonal School, I wish to inform you that it was not through neglect that this school was not repaired last year. Material and help were not available, and cement could not be procured at any cost.

The school must be raised and some of the heavy timbers replaced, also new piers or a foundation will have to be built, and a veranda and steps.

The school needs to be painted inside and outside; the interior, walls, and desks, should be cleaned and varnished. I estimate, the labour will cost approximately $100.

Paint can be procured here in the wholesale, and the quantity needed, will be:

- 6 gallons of White paint, at $4.75 a gal.
- 1 gallon of varnish, at 6.27 a gal.
- 1 gallon of turpentine, at 2.50 a gal.
- 1 gallon of boiled oil, at 2.00 a gal.

There is no doubt, with the increase in cost of labour and material, that $100 should be added to the previous estimate submitted for the repair of the school.

J. A. Marleau,
INDIAN AGENT.
Ottawa, April 25th, 1947.

Mr. J.A. Marleau, Indian Agent,

With reference to your letter of the 23rd instant regarding the Bear Island School, the Department approves painting this building interiorly and exteriorly. It is noted the cost of labour will be approximately $100.

6 gallons of White paint @ $4.75 a gal.
1½ gallons of Varnish @ 6.27 a gal.
1 gallon of Turpentine @ 2.50 a gal.
1 gallon of Boiled Oil @ 2.00 a gal.

We also approve the other necessary repairs to this building and trust that you will keep the cost as low as possible.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have the honour to forward herewith attached a requisition for School supplies for the Trout Lake Band of Indians, as presented to me by the Rev. L. Garrett the clergyman there. The Rev. The population of the band is now estimated at 757. Mr. Garrett owing to the nomadic mode of life of the band does not consider that an established school is necessary nor does he wish to give all of his time to the school but will give as much as he can as soon as the supplies arrive. Dear Sir:

I am here enclosing my request for School Supplies, as it was proposed to do last summer. We had quite a severe outbreak of flu just a few days after you left us, which prevented the from opening school before Aug 8th, but from that date until Sep 7th inclusive the children worked very well. I closed school on Sep 7th on being called away to visit the Indians at Round Lake and decided not to reopen school again until next spring on account of our shortage of School supplies.

We are also very badly off for drugs this winter having nothing at all off some of the important items such as Castor oil, Cod liver oil and Aspirin. Fortunately though up to the present time the health of the band has been very good this winter.

Dear Mr. Abery,

The Indians are getting out logs again to put up a school building. I am writing to ask if you will send us plans for a smaller building. The plan you sent Sep 1932 provided for a two-roomed school to accommodate 80 pupils.

As the Indians are going in more for gardening out on their reservations and winter quarters, the general trend seems to be more and more to hang off after treat time from the mission.

Owing also to so much of the transportation being done by plane there is somewhat less freighting for the Indians to do.

So I feel a small school say to accommodate 50 or 60 pupils would be more practicable and the Church could be used during the few weeks of rush around treaty time. Perhaps an one-room school would be most suitable under these conditions. I will be very if you would be so

Dear Mr. Neary:

The Rev. Leslie Garrett of Big Trout Lake in the Sioux Lookout Agency has appealed to me for an Indian Day School teacher for the summer. He has also I understand spoken of the same matter to Mr. Swartman, the Indian Agent.

There is, as you know, no school at Trout Lake, but they have in former years had a seasonal teacher.

I have received a letter from Mr. Harold Garrett, the son of the above-named clergyman, offering his services as teacher in response to the appeal of his father. In his application he states in part as follows:

"I will be nineteen years old in May, and am in my fourth year at Westdale Collegiate, Hamilton. I expect to have my Junior Matriculation this spring. As a King's Scout and Assistant Scout Master I have had experience in working with boys, and last summer I helped conduct a one week Scout Camp."

It will be seen that he has not technical qualifications of a teacher, but in the very elementary subjects which could be taught at Trout Lake, guided by the missionary, he should be able to provide helpful service, and perhaps lead him to later seek qualifications by further study.

As his qualifications are thus stated I do not think it would be of any value to send him the usual form, copies of which you sent to me some time ago.

Would it possible for you to approve of Harold Garrett going in to Trout Lake as teacher for the summer? If you would kindly inform me, I will communicate with him further, and if you approve he might go in to the mission with me in June, or by a freight plane from Sioux Lookout.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

In September of last year an agreement was entered into between the Indians of the Tyendinaga reserve and the whites who are lessors of Indian lands in reference to the management of the schools.

By the terms of this agreement the Indians are responsible for the equipment of the schools in accordance with the regulations of your Department.

It appears that there was some delay in equipping the schools as ordered by the Public School Inspector, Mr. Clarke, and in consequence the moiety of the teacher's salary payable by the whites was withheld. The teacher complained to this Department and instructions have been given to the Indian Agent to provide the equipment called for without loss of time. The Department, however, wishes to point out to you that Mr. Clarke is insisting upon the maximum equipment for these schools; in fact some of the articles are not to be found in the public schools of the city of Ottawa, nor in the school in the village of Deseronto, which is in the same inspectorate.

Memorandum to Chief Accountant:

In view of the fact that conditions, past and present, with regard to our schools at Tyendinaga reserve have been and still are far from satisfactory, I think that it would be advisable for Mr. Benson to visit the agency and schools with the new agent with a view to having the work properly opened at the coming school term.

The present agent has not been long in office and consequently is not familiar with our school work. I understand that certain repairs are necessary to the buildings, new desks are needed, (in some cases), and that maps and certain other requirements are sadly lacking. It is not likely that the new agent would be in a position to take these various matters up and deal with them as intelligently as would Mr. Benson. There seems to be some dissatisfaction, also, with regard to the matter of teachers which could also be taken up at the same time. If my suggestion is followed, the new agent would be started with a proper equipment and a clean slate, so far as school work is concerned and the department could reasonably expect more favorable reports than otherwise.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.

I beg to submit the following monthly report in connection with Tyendinaga Indian Agency for the month ending December 31st, 1937.

SCHOOLS

I visited the four day schools on the reserve several times during the month, and on each occasion found the attendance fair, the pupils clean and bright and progress good. During the past month the weather conditions have been fair with the exception of two days when a very heavy fall of snow made it necessary to close the schools for two days, owing to the fact that the roads on the reserve were completely blocked, however as soon as roads were cleared of snow the schools re-opened and attendance was very fair for the time of the year. At the close of schools for the Xmas. vacation, each teacher arranged a concert programme to which the parents were invited to attend, the pupils singing carols and giving short plays in memory of the Xmas. season, at the close of the programme each pupil was given a bag of candies and an orange the usual treat supplied by the department.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

I note with interest that it is your intention to discuss the matter of school attendance with the truant officer and the local constable, and it is my hope that you will find it convenient to do so at an early date. You might also discuss the matter with the School Inspector, himself.

I want to state frankly that it is not the intention of the Department to keep the schools at Tyendinaga open and in operation for a full 10 month period next year, unless the attendance during the month of September is substantially increased. I cannot overlook the fact that there are a great many public schools throughout Canada operating on the 8 month basis, and I do not feel that we would be fair to the tax payers to keep schools open and in operation in the early months of the academic year with about one third of the pupils enrolled in attendance. Would it be possible or practicable to have two schools remain closed until October and two kept open? This is a matter that should be discussed with the members of the Band, the parents and the teachers in charge of the schools. The Inspector takes the position that the attendance has been unsatisfactory over a period of years. The Department feels that the time has come when a definite understanding should be reached with respect to the operation of the schools in the future.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report in connection with Tyendinaga Indian Agency, for the month ending November 30th, 1938.

Schools

The school attendance has improved during the past month but there is still room for further improvement. I find that in a good many cases of absentees that it is the children of white parents, tenants holding lands under lease, that are keeping the average down. I think it might be as well if the Department considered some system in regard to children of white parents attending Indian day schools, especially since under the new regulations no school taxes are charged on leases now being issued. My opinion is that if parents of white children resident on the reserve wish to receive the benefit of our schools, then they should at least send their children regular, and if they are not interested enough to do so, then the Indian Agent should have authority to refuse them admittance. At the present time the Indian Agent has no jurisdiction over white parents resident on the reserve who have children of school age; the Indian Act applies to Indian children only.

Dear Sir -

I understand that Indian Affairs comes under your supervision, & am writing to you to take a personal interest in the teachers of Indian schools here, on the Tyendinaga reserve near Deseronto.

We read in our 'Daily' papers, nearly every day of salaries being increased on account of the higher cost of living, & yet the teachers of these four schools had their salaries decreased by one month's salary in 1940.

My daughter, Jean Schell, has been a teacher on the reserve, 6 miles from Deseronto, until last month when she ree'd leave of absence to go into war work. Her year's salary had been $900. However, last year she was notified that the Indian schools on the reserve would be closed for the month of Sept. to save expenses for the Government, & my daughter & the other three teachers on the reserve lose a month's pay & the Indian children were deprived of their school.

There was no good reason for this move on the part of the Indian Department. I ask that the salary for the month of Sept. 1940 be restored to these teachers.

The Indian schools here are under the Inspector of Public Schools for the Province of Ont., & the teachers are expected to cover the same work & course of study that the other Ont. schools do, & that means that 10 months work has to be covered in 9, & a great deal more work for the teacher, & they earn their money & need it in every case.

*******

Dear Madam:

In the absence of the Minister I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of July 3 with reference to the salary payments to the teachers of the Indian day schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

After giving the matter very careful consideration it was decided last year to reduce the academic term at Indian day schools from ten months to nine months. This was partly due to the fact that our records showed a very unsatisfactory attendance at Indian day schools during the month of September.

All teachers were advised in May of 1940 regarding the proposed change which would take effect in the academic year 1940-41. This Department does not bind any teacher with a contract and in view of the date on which we notified each teacher of the change in length of the academic year 1940-41 any teacher was at liberty to secure a better position if desired.

All teachers of Indian day schools in the Dominion of Canada were treated in a similar manner and you will, therefore, realize the impossibility of carrying out your suggestion regarding the teachers on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

Yours sincerely,

I would wish the decision of the Department as to whether Winston Fuller aged 14 and Kenneth Fuller aged 13 should be allowed to attend Central Indian day school on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

These two children are sons of Clayton Fuller, a white citizen of the Township of Thurlow in the County of Hastings and their mother was a daughter of Mrs. Joe Hill and a member of the Tyendinaga Band before her marriage to Clayton Fuller. Some ten years or so ago and while resident off the reserve Mrs. Clayton Fuller died and after her death the grand-mother with the consent of the father of the children removed them to the reserve where they have been ever since and Mrs. Joe Hill from time to time received funds from Clayton Fuller for the support of the children.

These Fuller children of whom there were four at the time their mother died have all been allowed to remain on the reserve for years and received their education at the Central School and recently Mrs. Joe Hill complained to me that she was not receiving any support from their father for their keep and I instructed her that this was a matter for the court to decide and that in my opinion these children should not be on the reserve but should be with their father in Thurlow Township. I have your letter of December 22nd with reference to Winston and Kenneth Fuller, sons of Clayton Fuller, who are resident with their grand-mother Mrs. Joseph Hill on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve and would wish to advise you that these boys are now reported to be 14 and 15 years old.

Their father was charged before Magistrate J. L. Lloyd, Magistrate, Belleville, Ont. on December 17th, with non-support under section 242(3B) of the Criminal Code and the case was dismissed by the Magistrate. From information that I have gained the plaintiff in this case Mrs. Joseph Hill did have to admit to the court that these two boys did considerable of the work on the farm of the plaintiff and that they milked cows, ran the farm tractor, ploughed land, harvested hay and other crops and in fact were doing most of the farm work and were considered by the court to be self maintaining.

The father of the children wanted to take them home with him, but the grand-mother would not agree to this claiming that they could not run their farm without the boys who on account of their age and ability are valuable to grand-mother who has raised them since they were small and who is entitled to some consideration for her past outlay on their behalf. The father of the children then agreed that he would pay $20.00 a month towards their keep, but that the children would have to go to school, which has brought up the point as to their being allowed to attend an Indian school as the children are of white status. These children have always been only fair attendants at the Central school due to their being kept at home to assist on the farm and this is the point their father objected to in not paying for their support in the past. Personally I do not see that these children should be deprived of an education and do consider that there are others in the farm household that could show more exertion and use the boys less to do the farm work, which is the contentious point put up by the defendant at the court.

REPORT ON TYDENAGA AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JANUARY 1943.

Education.

Considering the weather conditions during January the school attendance retained its average and all schools did remain open despite blocked roads and zero weather. Manual training materials were supplied for woodwork and sewing materials for the girls to all schools during the month. Miss Stoddart, teacher of Eastern School reports that her 9th grade pupils are doing well in their studies and the Ontario Department of Education examiner does give them very good marks on their papers submitted to that department. The new Council of the Tyendinaga Band have again been requested to give their co-operation in an endeavor to increase the attendance at the schools by contacting their fellow band members and advising them of the benefits of educating their children. I reported to the Council the case of one young Indian named Baptiste, whose home was a mile from the Western school and who was rejected from the Armed services due to the fact he could not read nor write and this was the fault of his parents in not sending him to school and I believe there are others of a like nature which should not be on a reserve that is advanced in all other progressive pursuits.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1943.

Education. While the weather improved and it was somewhat warmer during March, certain sections were flooded from spring freshet making it impossible for children from these districts to attend school from time to time and in spite of this the attendance was better than in February. The parents of a number of 14 and 15 yr. old pupils have applied at this office seeking permission to remove their children from school to take employment and I have granted permits to two boys over 15, whom the teacher reported as wasting their time at school and were a poor influence on the younger children. Children under 15 were ordered to remain at school despite the protests of the parents who desire them to secure employment which is plentiful.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Deseronto, Ont. April 14, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

I would wish to advise you that Mrs Ella Claus teacher of the Central Indian Day School has submitted her written resignation to this office. This resignation to take effect at the end of April and is due to ill health as Mrs Claus is an expectant mother in the fall. The written resignation is enclosed and recommended for approval by the Department.

There is on the Reserve, living a third of a mile from the school, a Mrs Eva Brant whom I have interviewed and who is agreeable to take over this school to complete the present academic year. Mrs Brant while holding no certificate has had a year at Normal School and taught over 2 years, previous to her marriage, on a permit and I am sure she has the ability to take charge of this school and would recommend she be engaged for May and June at $85.00 a month.

As there are 2 entrance pupils and the regular promotion examinations during this period, it would be very much to the disadvantage of the pupils to close the school for want of a teacher. This position could be advertised during the coming summer holidays in an endeavour to procure a proper qualified teacher holding a certificate.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 19, 1943.

REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1943.

Education;

The attendance at the reserve schools during June was lower than in May, due to children being kept at home to assist in planting canning tomatoes and garden crops. Six children of the reserve have tried their entrance examinations, two being promoted on their years work and the other four having to take the exams. The school and grounds at the Eastern, Western and Central schools have been well kept by the pupils in their program to improve the looks of these schools. Little improvement was made at the mission school, where the grounds are not very favourable for much improvement.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Deseronto, Ont. July 2nd 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

So far as is known at the present time all teachers with the exception of Mrs. Eva Brant have signified their intention of returning to their duties at the re-opening of the schools of the Agency in September next.

Mrs. Brant took over the duties of Mrs. Ella Claus on the 1st of May last at the Central Day school and very capably did her duty to the satisfaction of all concerned. Mrs. Brant was only engaged for the two months and your authority is requested to advertise in the Toronto Globe and Mail for a new teacher, as I have already been making enquiries locally and am unable to line up a teacher for this school. If the Department has not a candidate in view for this school the only recourse is advertising and I would wish to be advised of the salary offered, which in my opinion should not be less than $90.00, plus bonus, per month, in an endeavor to get a properly qualified teacher at this time when they are quite scarce.

Mrs. Gladys Maracle, teacher of the Mission Day School was to be replaced when a suitable teacher could be procured for that school and in advertising it is possible enough applications would be secured that a replacement could be made from the applicants for Central School, if not it may be necessary to carry on with Mrs. Maracle for another term. On account of the residence available at Mission School, the salary would be fair at $85.00 a month, plus bonus.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 6, 1943.

Mr. A. D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont.

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, in reference to the teacher of the Tyendinaga Central School.

In a recent report on his inspection of this school, Inspector McGuire reported quite favourably on the work of Mrs. Eva Brant. Is she willing to continue for the academic year 1943-44? If so, I believe we should retain her services. Teachers are extremely scarce this year, and this applies all over Canada. Consequently any teacher that we have in our employ at the present time, who is reasonably satisfactory, should be kept, if at all possible.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Deseronto, Ont. July 16th 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I have your letter of July 6th with reference to the engagement of a teacher for the Central Indian Day School and reporting that Inspector McGuire had given Mrs. Eva Brant a quite favourable report and inquiring as to the willingness of Mrs. Brant to continue for the academic year 1943-44.

While Mrs. Brant in June signified that she was not willing, on account of help shortage on their farm, to continue teaching for the new academic year, she has now agreed that she will return to the school in September and continue teaching as long as it is possible and she is able to obtain the services of a girl to do her housework while teaching.

As Mrs. Brant has met the approval of the Inspector and gets along quite well with the pupils of her school, her appointment for the coming academic year is recommended for your approval and her appointment will be on the understanding that should she desire to leave she will give a month's notice, to which she is agreeable.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

REPORT ON TYENDINAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF AUGUST, 1943.

Schools;

The work of repairs to the interior of the Mission School was practically completed, with a small amount of painting to be done, through inability to procure at short notice the kind of paint that was supplied through the Dept. The schools have all been cleaned and are in readiness for the opening of school Sept. 1st. It is suggested that the opening and closing of Indian Schools be adjusted in future to confirm with the dates of other schools in Ontario, which are not to open till the 7th of September, the date when I expect to see the Indian pupils return, although the schools will open on the 1st to confirm with your schedule.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.
